The historically recent growth of centralized digital money has resulted in the transformation of money from being a medium of exchange, to many officials viewing it as primarily a medium of law enforcement. This is increasingly making such money more local and less trustworthy. https:// twitter.com/CatoCMFA/statu s/961712965866151936 …

ERP & similar would be interesting experiments to watch from a safe distance. They would have programmers making legal and accounting decisions, or (more likely in the long run) an unpredictable variety of local lawyers & accountants getting involved in global software upgrades. https:// twitter.com/TokenHash/stat us/961472796315369472 …

Trust-minimized governance uses tech to minimize the kinds of decisions leaders are expected to, or in the most secure cases even able to, make. This can lower governance costs & increase social scalability dramatically: the best public blockchains work seamlessly across borders.

I believe Wences himself made the same mistake in the podcast where he thought those were "my" arguments or opinions. They're not. They're arguments I've heard on the other side, and I wanted to hear his rebuttal to them.

Yes, it's true that in that very moment I couldn't recall two of the three points he had just said but I thought of the counterarguments I've heard and so said those. However, the question about how he would address the critiques was still relevant.

You have no idea what was going on in my head. Some very prominent VCs in the space point to those aspects of Ethereum when they express their view that Ethereum will eclipse Bitcoin. I was thinking of how they might critique Wences’s view and used that to form my question.

You don’t know what I recognize or don’t recognize from my questions. In every single episode, I ask questions I know the answers to just to get the guest to say them, and I don’t ask questions based on my personal opinions but often based on how critics would debate that person.

I personally have learned an immense amount of correct things from “experts” who have been wrong about certain other things.

But a person’s credibility is only relevant to whether you choose to believe or trust them, either on a point of fact or a rule of thumb. Not whether you can confirm their claims, or follow their reasoning.
One error might well have the same roots as another error. But one error does not imply another error. Get my distinction?
It’s true of course that you might identify certain habits of thought or character traits that lead to a person being wrong repeatedly. But that is a different argument.
They bear the (perhaps profound) responsibility for being wrong. But it actually doesn’t have any logical bearing on whether they’re right or wrong about something else.
The problem is, because everyone has been wrong, this argument can be used to not listen to anyone.
I’m not, btw, responding to someone’s criticism of me. It’s just an argument I hear constantly these days, about other people.

This notion that you can point to one thing - even a quite significant thing - that a person was wrong about, and draw the conclusion that they are wrong about whatever they are saying now is a particularly inane idea. We have all been wrong about something.
